triples.name: Mate choice in humans
triples.relevance: The paper directly studies human mate preferences and choices across multiple cultures.

triples.name: Sex differences in psychology
triples.relevance: The paper examines universal sex differences in mate preferences between men and women.

triples.name: Evolutionary psychology
triples.relevance: One of the two competing theoretical perspectives used to explain the observed mate preference patterns.

triples.name: Biosocial theory
triples.relevance: The alternative theoretical perspective used to explain sex differences in mate preferences alongside evolutionary psychology.

triples.name: Physical attractiveness
triples.relevance: A key dimension of mate preference that the paper found men prefer more than women.

triples.name: Gender equality
triples.relevance: A cultural variable tested in the study to predict sex differences in mate preferences across countries.

triples.name: Cross-cultural studies
triples.relevance: The methodological approach used to examine mate preferences across 45 countries.

triples.name: Replication
triples.relevance: The paper explicitly attempts to replicate classic studies on mate preferences using new data.

triples.name: Prevalence
triples.relevance: The paper measures pathogen prevalence as an environmental variable hypothesized to predict mate preferences.

triples.name: Human mating strategies
triples.relevance: The paper examines the sex-differentiated mating strategies and preferences that evolved to solve reproductive challenges.

triples.name: Dataset
triples.relevance: The paper proposes a new 45-country cross-cultural dataset (N=14,399) to test theories of mate preferences using updated methodology and data.
